title: Friday, 6th July, 2018
bodyHTML:

BE11:09am

11:09 am

So ..... to recap the news, Echostar offered 532p per share on July 3, about half in cash.

pancakes or waffles as a sidenote, the world cup is back today. i have felt lost during the last 48 hours but help is finally here
BE11:11am

(You'll remember Inmarsat fell quite sharply that day on rumours that Echostar was trying to force the issue pre Independence Day.)

BE11:11am

Inmarsat told them to go away on July 4.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Echostar now looking for an extension to the PUSU, but will need Inmarsat's cooperation for that.

nichoman surely echostar didn't actually think they'd be successful at £5.32 ?
Grouchmonkey Over? Surely not. Would be optimistic if Echostar thought 532 was enough
Grouchmonkey snap
BE11:12am

Is that possible? Maybe, depending on how things pan out in the shareholder meetings going on at this exact moment.

nichoman :)
BornCynic Morning
BE11:13am

Here's Wilton Fry, RBC's resident Inmarsat bull.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

We believe it would be difficult for the Inmarsat board to agree to a PUSU extension without any further proposal by Echostar as the board has already rejected the proposal. In our view, the statement by Echostar at 7am today enables both Echostar’s and Inmarsat’s advisors to go directly to shareholders, with Echostar’s proposal in hand, to gauge their collective reaction.

BE11:13am

In our view, the offer is a ‘low ball’ one, especially given the potential £10 per share of spectrum value that we believe Echostar could derive from owning Inmarsat. However it may be the right level to start a conversation with shareholders along the lines of “…well at what level would you start the negotiation at?”.

Depending on the feedback both parties receive, Echostar could (1) either raise its proposal in the hope that Inmarsat requests a PUSU extension (which would allow a negotiation), (2) table a formal offer, either at the current proposal price (unlikely), or a higher price, (3) let the deadline lapse and enter a private conversation with Inmarsat with aim of a reaching an agreed recommendation, (4) walk away.

Grouchmonkey Hard for Inmarsat directors not to agree an extension, given their fiduciary duty to shareholders
BE11:14am

(@Grouchmonkey: possibly, but impossible to engage unless Echostar raises, having done the "fundamentally undervalued" thing.)

Maverick Gents a lot going around on Integrafin, heard anything r.e. Bid Spec...?
Hamster on a Piano dwadline lapse & walk away is effectively the same thing. 2.8 announcement surely
11:15 am
BE11:15am

And Jefferies.

BE11:16am

(@Hamster: yeah, I'd note RBC is suggesting there that Echostar/Inmarsat break the law. You can't have private conversations once you're in the six-month purgatory period.)

BE11:16am

EchoStar's revised offer of 532p/share has not surprisingly been rejected by Inmarsat (massive FCF per share accretion, well below intrinsic value). EchoStar will for now continue to pursue the recommended offer route, but given the evident "bid-ask" spread, and Ergen / EchoStar's evident unwillingness to bid-up in uncontested M&A, we could see EchoStar turn hostile in time.

BornCynic Anyone clock what the Singapore government has done to their property market?
11:18 am
BE11:19am

Now, Inmarsat lacks a key shareholder. Lansdowne, Jupiter, Artemis are all big but none big enough to lead the negotiation here.

BE11:19am

You also have some concerns about Echostar's ability to pay much more.

BE11:19am

Here's Numis.

alewis2005 Happy friday people
11:20 am
BE11:20am

EchoStar has c.£3.5bn EV and just 0.5x net debt/EBITDA. It earns most value from selling satellite broadband connectivity in the US and the Americas, and delivering TV channels for Dish, its sister company. Charles Ergen controls both corporates and is also heavily invested in US spectrum. EchoStar overlaps little with ISAT's business so cost savings will be minor; it has no real involvement in L-band businesses (greater than 80% of ISAT's sales) so revenue synergies will be minor also. In addition, EchoStar may have to give up its European S-band license as ISAT owns the other of the two.

BE11:20am

Some believe EchoStar will table a firm offer for ISAT because it is interested in the target’s spectrum; the view is that EchoStar will ask regulatory permission to use this spectrum for terrestrial (rather than satellite) mobile services. The risks for EchoStar are significant, not least because those who to date have paid very high prices in auctions for terrestrial mobile spectrum will object vociferously.

BE11:21am

Which ties back to a point we've made repeatedly here. If we're seeing Inmarsat as a strategic asset because of its involvement with Ligado, buying it is a binary gamble on Ligado's regulatory approval.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Ergen likes a gamble. But how much?

nichoman @BornCynic no what have they done ?
JimboRock DLG shareprice in need of Winston Wolf - any info appreciated
BornCynic Nichoman - thrown a bucket of cold water on it. Try googling "Singapore Announces Surprise Property Curbs to Cool Market"

You'll note that Echostar doesn't make any reference to Ligado in its "strategically compelling" statement this morning.

JuB need a CVR to define the FCC/Ligado risk
BE11:24am

As UBS says ...............

11:24 am
BE11:25am

LN can lead to a wide range of valuations for Inmarsat and could be a substantial driver of EchoStar's interest. We value the underlying Inmarsat business at 340p, .....

BE11:25am

So, it's a gamble on both sides of the trade. Clearly.

BE11:25am

Anyway, we'll come back to it if there's anything else before midday.

Barclays first. Direct Line goes down to equal weight and ESure to underweight. Targets of 357p and 220p respectively.

StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst hello folks
BE11:30am

The soft market in uk motor insurance continues with further pricing declines in April-May. however, pricing itself is not as important as the spread between prices and claims. While the initial reduction in the Ogden discount rate led to c12% price increases, the partial reversal in Ogden and the potential for whiplash reform has resulted in pricing falling 8-9% from the peak. Although this is entirely rational, market cycles tend to overshoot, particularly as all the listed players are looking for growth (from low single digits at Direct Line to high single digits at esure and hastings) – and our proprietary analysis shows Aviva and Allianz⁄LFF= take share too. We expect management teams to have more cautious guidance at 1h18 results and we factor in pricing of -3% for 2018 and flat for 2019, leading to 1-9$ EpS cuts for 2018-2020. We also increase our cost of equity to 9.5% for hastings and esure, reflecting the risks from their growth ambitions. generous dividend yields of 6-8% are currently the biggest argument in favor of uk motor insurers, but payout is directly linked to earnings – lower earnings would therefore lead to lower dividends.

StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst Did we already talk about tarriffs re china and europe

We cut the most liquid sector name Direct Line to Equal Weight, expect consensus EpS cuts from 1h18 and highlight dividend risk as the payout is above 100%. for esure we expect aggressive growth amid lower shoparounds to result in weakening technical profitability, and see the biggest earnings risks in 2019-20. We now rate the stock underweight despite weak recent performance.

StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst i did @excel - nothing there
BE11:32am

Sector view:

Grouchmonkey 20% Additional Buyers Stamp Duty rate - ouch! Makes London sound comparatively cheap.
BE11:33am

UK life insurers have underperformed the European insurance index by 1.5% YTD. Within this sub-sector, the key underperformers are Just Group (-20%) and Prudential (-8%) while Aviva is relatively outperforming. In our view, Aviva and SJP offer the best risk-reward as 1) Aviva’s total capital return is c8.5% in 2018e/19e whereas b) SJP continues to offer strong organic growth (10-12% net inflows % of AUM). Prudential’s shares have been impacted by the weak performance of its US life peers and we believe this is overdone as US macro indicators are tracking satisfactorily. In our view, the regulatory development for annuities geared businesses is not favourable given the recent –ve news around risk margin and the treatment of equity release mortgages under S-II. In absence of other catalysts, we think that the risk-reward opportunity at Just Group isn’t attractive and hence we d/g it to UW (from N) with a new Dec-19 PT of 137p (vs 166p before). We reiterate our OW on Aviva and SJP, N on Prudential and UW on LGEN.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

And on the bulks specifically ............

BE11:33am

Recently the PRA announced that it not considering a reduction to the risk margin buffer contrary to what was widely expected by UK life insurers and by some investors. The PRA has also started consultation for the treatment of equity release mortgages under Solvency II (key asset class for annuities). In light of these developments and an absence of other catalysts, we remain cautious on the risk-reward offered by annuities geared businesses and therefore downgrade Just Group to UW (from N).

..... which, just from a perspective of logic, seems more sensible than an ITV bid. There are several UK mobile operators open to offers at the moment and they'd fold into Virgin Media a lot easier than a terrestrial broadcaster beholden to advertising trends.

BE11:39am

But, hey, what do I know. Here's the topline from SocGen.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

ITV’s share price has dropped sharply since its 2016 high, losing -38% absolute and -34% relative to Stoxx Europe 600 Media. We review the ten major concerns that supported our Sell rating and conclude that five have flipped around or reached their natural inflection points, i.e. moved past the point of peak pain. With a more stable outlook for UK TV advertising, we upgrade our FY18e and FY19e EPS forecasts by +17% and +24% respectively, raise our TP from 150p to 220p (higher EPS estimates, +2% LT growth vs +1.5%) and upgrade our rating from Sell to Buy.

BE11:45am

Raised land acquisition costs affect new land purchases but not existing landbank, and both CDL and UOL substantially grew their landbanks in the past 1-2 years. We also believe home prices can continue a path of positive, albeit more moderate, price appreciation despite cooling measures (see Singapore Property and Banks: Property Cooling Kicks Off - 6 July 2018). Evidence from the past cycle show that immediate negative share price reactions to cooling tend to reverse in 2-3 months on signs that home prices and volumes continue to grow, and we think the current selldown is overdone.

BE11:47am

Citi:

BE11:47am

Should banks be worried about a property slowdown and household debt? — Banks in Singapore are typically sanguine about residential mortgages because this consistently has one of the lowest NPL histories of any loan class. Absolute loss rates are also low because of collateral cover (based on discussions with the banks we believe average mortgage LTVs are around 60%). The new LTV caps look to discourage new borrowing for investment properties, which we believe comprise 20-25% of total mortgages. Perhaps a medium term concern for regulators (hence helping to explain the timing of these measures) is higher mortgage interest rates and the rising burden on debt servicing ratio (DSR). Sensitivity studies suggest that for households with 2 private properties and a car loan, present DSR could rise from 35% to 43% assuming mortgage rates rise from 2.3% in 2018E to 2.8% by 2019E. While this still should not result in a major NPL problem (unless a spike in unemployment also occurs), it would hurt consumption capacity and ability to take on further borrowings, both of which could impact banks’ revenue growth.
